Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation2: A procedural hearing on a minor matter can easily be postponed if necessary.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means so much to your grandmother.” My heart squeezed. This ceremony was more than a ritual—it was a thread tying generations together, and my family expected me to honor it, to show I hadn’t forgotten where I came from. But my calendar blinked with a court hearing scheduled for the same morning. It was a minor case, one that could be postponed, but I knew my client was anxious, counting on me to be there, to show that their concerns mattered. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family’s pride and tradition on one side, my professional duty and my client’s trust on the other. I could almost hear my grandmother’s voice, gentle but firm, and my client’s nervous questions echoing in my mind. My chest tightened as I tried to imagine disappointing either side, knowing that whatever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
